outputs.output_descr: UNDP works to address the social and economic impacts of the epidemic through the provision of tools to assess the socio-economic costs of AIDS, and by implementing strategies to mitigate impact of AIDS

a) UNDP Promotes attention to leadership and rights of women and girls as part of HIV responses, with particular attention to women living with HIV and marginalized women. Support is provided to country programmes in: mainstreaming/integration of HIV into gender programmes and gender into HIV programmes; supporting leaderships development programmes; programmes focus on MARP to reduce their vulnertability to HIV; b) UNDP supports national capacity strengthening for inclusive governance and coodination of AIDS responses by promoting participation of civil society entities and people living with HIV in the design, implementation and evaluation of AIDS programmes. UNDP supports the documentation of different examples of good practices in national coordination of AIDS response

Act 9: Rights, Law and Stigma: "Implementation of human rights based programming approaches and promotion of enabling legal environments, including prevention of inappropriate criminalization of HIV transmission, legislative review and reform, and enforcement of laws to protect HIV-related rights and gender equality,"  and "strengthened country capacity to design and implement programmes to reduce HIV-related stigma and address key social determinants of vulnerability, including through partnerships with people living with HIV, civil society organizations, women's groups, religious leaders and media." 

Act 10:  Gender and Gender Based Violence:  "Promotion of enabling environment to address gender-dimensions of AIDS, advance human rights of women and girls, support active engagement of women living with HIV and gender advocates in HIV responses, promote links and reciprocal capacity building between AIDS organizations and women's groups, and strengthen networks of men and boys to address gender inequality," and "integration of women, girls and gender equality (including the role of men and boys) into national AIDS strategies, annual action plans and sector plans, with specific attention to implementation of programmes, budgeting and allocation of funds."

Act 11: Sexual Diversity:  "Promotion of enabling environment to respond to HIV among men who have sex with men and transgender populations, including through reduction of stigma and discrimination, responses to violations of human rights, and strengthened linkages between AIDS organizations and LGBT groups," and "integration of attention to men who have sex with men and transgender populations in national AIDS strategies and programmes, annual action plans and sector plans, including budgeting and allocation of funds."

Act 12:  Intellectual Property, Innovation and Access to Treatment:  "Strengthened national capacity for enabling trade and health policies and programmes that promote sustainable access to AIDS medicines" (UBW    Activity)
Programme management support for salaries and related costs
Latin America and Caribbean: HIV Staff Salary
